report_title: Boat Dealership and Repair in the US
executive_summary: The Boat Dealership and Repair industry retails new and used boats, including canoes, sailboats, motorboats and boat parts and accessories. Boat dealers also offer repair and maintenance services, and mechanics may be employed by a boat dealer or operate independently. For most of the past five years, increasing per capita disposable income and a healthy economy have supported industry growth.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Because of the unique environment brought on by the coronavirus, the industry had a large spike in demand and revenue in 2020, despite poor economic conditions. Social distancing requirements and decreases in travel because of the virus boosted industry demand. For example, social distancing requirements forced consumers to engage in activities with small groups in isolated locations. Boating activities with limited people fit these conditions and were permitted in all 50 states, making it popular.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Rising Boat Use Supports Revenue Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the last five years, consumers have had greater disposable income available to allocate toward leisure activities. This has prompted individuals to spend more time on leisure and sports and increase their recreation expenditure. Low fuel costs and interest rates during the period have also aided in consumers' decision to purchase a boat. Strong economic conditions during most of the period, in addition to the unique circumstances of 2020, have supported industry growth through increased boat use.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Demand for Repair and Maintenance Supports Revenue Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Repair and maintenance for boats can be costly. But, even during periods of low disposable income and consumer sentiment, boat owners are more inclined to make repairs on boats rather than buy new vessels. The increase in boat usage has spurred demand for boat repair services over the past five years. As people use the boats more, routine maintenance and repair services for the vessels are needed more frequently.

Because of their high cost, boats are normally considered discretionary and luxury purchases. As boats are a significant expenditure, demand for industry products and services highly depends on disposable income and consumer confidence levels. Per capita disposable income will increase over the next five years, making large-scale purchases, like boats, more feasible for prospective buyers.

As global travel restrictions and social distancing regulations are lifted following the coronavirus, consumers will spend more money on vacations or activities that they had to previously postpone instead of on boats. Boat rental companies will also gain popularity as higher interest rates make purchasing a boat less attractive than during the previous five-year period.

Boat dealers employ numerous marine mechanics to provide repair and maintenance services. Repair services may be performed under or out of warranty, but some boat manufacturers only permit repairs performed under warranty at authorized dealerships. Over the next five years, demand for repair services will increase in response to the large increase in boat sales and use in the previous five-year period.

industry_definition: This industry sells new and used recreational boats such as canoes, sailboats and motorboats (except personal watercraft), boat parts and accessories. This industry also provides repair and maintenance services; boat repairers may be employed by a boat dealer or operate as an independent shop.

threats: Time spent on leisure and sports

key_trends: COVID-19 benefited boat dealerships. Boat sales increased in 2020 as consumers could participate in boating activities despite social distancing restrictions.
Boat rental companies will threaten sales. Boat rental companies are increasingly popular since consumers do not have to commit to purchasing and storing a boat.
Industry Associations Assist Dealerships. The MRAA provides educational, advocacy and business development support for dealerships.
Dealerships Must Adhere to Regulations. Boat dealerships must obtain necessary licensing and adhere to EPA regulations.
Motorboats are the Most Popular Product Segment. Consumers are drawn to motorboats because of the variety of water activities that can be done with them.
Most Boat Owners Make Less Than $100,000 a Year. This highlights that even without high purchasing power, consumers choose to spend on industry products.
Population, Waterways and Income Levels Attract Dealers. Boat dealerships are also generally located close to suppliers, including boat manufacturers and wholesalers.
Boat Dealerships are Concentrated in Four Regions - Southeast, Great Lakes, Mid-Atlantic, West regions. These are the most populous regions and the regions closest to large water masses.
Boat Dealers Face High Internal Competition. Particularly in regions with nearby boating hubs.
Alternative Recreation Activities Challenge Boat Dealers. Various recreational businesses seek to capture consumers' leisure time and discretionary spending dollars.
Market Share Remains Low. Many boat dealers offer similar products to each other and compete on price and service.
Larger Companies are Increasing Merger and Acquisition Activities. Companies such as Marinemax have gained market share by acquiring smaller boat dealers or repair shops.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment includes households earning between $50,000 and $100,000 and represents the largest market for the industry. Consumers in this segment purchase boats for recreational activities like fishing, kayaking, wakeboarding and tubing. Because of these preferences, most boats purchased by this segment are small to medium-sized.

This segment includes all households earning more than $100,000 per year. According to the Recreational Boating and Fishing Foundation, 9.4% of these households own a boat. While many households in this segment own small to midsized boats, this segment also purchases larger and more expensive vessels.

This market segment includes households earning less than $50,000 per year and are the smallest segment of household consumers for the Boat Dealership and Repair industry. Consumers in this segment primarily purchase small- to mid-sized boats for recreational purposes. Since this segment has lower purchasing power, it is limited in its ability to make discretionary purchases.
This segment includes other retailers for resale and wholesalers for resale who purchase boats or repair services from boat dealers and repair shops.

products_and_services.product_description: New boats include new outboard and inboard motorboats, sailboats, canoes and kayaks. This industry does not include personal watercraft and small motorized vehicles designed for one to three riders.

Boat mechanics provide various parts and repair services, including steering alignment, light replacement and more substantial mechanical repairs. Other products offered by dealers include boating accessories, like boat cleaning supplies, paint, maintenance supplies, recreational equipment and various other miscellaneous merchandise.

Used boats include used outboard and inboard motorboats, sailboats, canoes and kayaks. This industry does not include personal watercraft and small motorized vehicles designed for one to three riders.

tier_1_suppliers: Storage & Warehouse Leasing in the US
Construction & Mining Equipment Wholesaling in the US
Electric Power Transmission in the US
Port & Harbor Operations in the US

tier_2_suppliers: Aircraft, Marine & Railroad Transportation Equipment Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_buyers: Port & Harbor Operations in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The Consumer Confidence Index measures consumer optimism regarding expected economic conditions, such as household finances, employment, business conditions and economic outlook. When consumer perceptions of the economy are high and positive, households spend freely on luxury items, like recreational boats.

Recreational boats are largely considered discretionary and luxury purchases, so a rise in household disposable income increases the propensity for consumers to purchase industry goods, boosting demand.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Time Spent on Leisure and Sports
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Fluctuations in consumer leisure time availability directly affect demand for industry products and services. An increase in leisure time leads to a rise in the number of individuals willing to spend time boating and ultimately, purchase industry goods or require industry repair services.

Boats with motors require gasoline to operate. So, a rise in the price of gasoline will increase the cost of using a boat. This cost increase can lead to a decline in boat usage, reducing demand for industry repair services.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast is the largest region by establishments and is home to the largest share of the US population. The greater the number of residents in a region, the stronger demand for industry products and services. Florida is the largest state by establishments in the region primarily because of the state's large number of bays, lakes and waterways.

The Great Lakes region is home to large lakes, such as Lake Erie, Lake Huron, Lake Michigan, Lake Ontario and Lake Superior. High water sport participation in this region leads to high demand for dealerships to fulfill. According to the Great Lake Information Network, the region has over 94,000 square miles of water, making it an attractive location for dealerships. Michigan is the largest state by establishments in the region.

Within the West region, California is a major boating area, making it the largest state by establishment. Boating areas include the coast and the California Delta, which comprise 1,000 miles of waterways and have over 100 marinas and waterside resorts. In addition, California has a higher-than-average median household income, which boosts demand as recreational boats are generally considered a luxury purchase.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Dealers must renew franchise and state licensing agreements annually. Franchise agreements protect a dealer's exclusive right to sell a specific brand within a specified radius.

Boat dealerships are subject to regulations imposed by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). For example, dealerships that store more than 10,000 pounds of gasoline or diesel fuel or reportable quantities of other chemicals, must submit an emergency and hazardous chemical inventory form to the local emergency planning commission, state emergency response commission and local fire department.

Industry operators must comply with the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA). According to the US Department of Labor, the federal minimum wage is $7.25 per hour effective July 24, 2009. States may also have minimum wage laws that provide greater employee protections. In this case, dealerships must comply with both.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Boat dealers require a skilled sales force and technicians, which can be costly to attract and retain.

basis_points.basis_description: Boat dealers face high internal competition, particularly in regions with nearby boating hubs.

basis_points.basis_title: Alternative recreation activities challenge boat dealers
basis_points.basis_description: Various recreational businesses seek to capture consumers' leisure time and discretionary spending dollars.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Many small players keeps concentration low
concentration_points.concentration_description: The Boat Dealership and Repair industry has a low level of market share concentration. The industry is highly fragmented, characterized by many small players that cater to local customers and regions.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Merger and acquisition activity is rising
concentration_points.concentration_description: Despite the industry's fragmented landscape, market share concentration has been on the rise over the past five years.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases are the largest cost for boat dealers
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Since this industry primarily focuses on retail, dealers spend the bulk of their revenue purchasing products. The purchase's share of industry revenue depends on a dealer's target market.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Profit varies based on product offerings and dealership size
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit, measured as earnings before interest and taxes, accounts for 6.9% of industry revenue in 2023, up from 6.2% in 2018. Boat dealers' profit varies depending on products, for example, dealers of specialized or luxury boats and niche services earn higher margins than those with more general product and service offerings.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Boat dealers require a skilled sales force and technicians
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Boat dealers require a skilled sales force and technicians, which can be costly to attract and retain.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The Discretionary Nature of Boats Increases Volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Since boats represent a discretionary purchase, demand fluctuates with changes in consumer sentiment and disposable income levels.
Revenue spiked in 2020 because of coronavirus-related social distancing regulations.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The rate of new patent additions to the industry is low. This is combined with a low concentration of innovation. Both factors being low suggests that new technology entry is slow and widespread, which limits the threat of disruptive threats hurting leading industry operators.

FAQs.question: How has your business adapted to the growth of online sales over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: While consumers have not fully become comfortable with making large purchases, such as boats, via the internet, many larger operators have begun expanding their online offerings to compete with the growing e-commerce market.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: This industry's growth is heavily dependent on the level of disposable income US residents have, as boats are largely a discretionary or luxury purchase.

FAQs.question: How do you contract directly with manufacturers in order to reduce purchase costs?
FAQs.answer: Dealer agreements between dealers and major boating manufacturers are a key industry feature.

FAQs.question: What is the Marine Retailers Association of the Americas (MRAA)?
FAQs.answer: The Marine Retailers Association of the Americas (MRAA) is the official North American industry trade organization, representing marine retailers, manufacturers and service providers across North America. The MRAA provides educational, advocacy and business development support for dealerships, along with an extensive network of partners to assist operators with branching out the business and navigating new markets.

FAQs.question: How do franchise agreements work in this industry?
FAQs.answer: These franchise agreements, which are normally valid for a set period of time, permit a dealer the right to exclusively sell boats within a defined primary geographic area.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in order to expand reach and reduce overhead expenses?
FAQs.answer: Many larger companies have begun acquiring smaller operators in order to increase their market share within the industry. Expanding the company through acquisitions will likely lower expenses. This is due to expanding the customer base and therefore being able to order parts and other relevant goods in bulk.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Since this industry relies on customer service and skilled technicians, operators will likely always depend on quality workers to remain efficiency. However, wage costs have decreased over the past five years which can be attributed to automating inventory and administrative systems that rely less heavily on skill.

FAQs.question: How has your company reacted to the rise of online sales over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Many larger companies have begun to expand their online offerings, while others have not felt the impact of online sales as strongly, as many consumers are still hesitant to make large purchases, such as boats, online.

FAQs.question: What does your company do to remain compliant with new consumer regulations?
FAQs.answer: Operators in the Boat Dealership and Repair industry must adhere with state and federal regulations that cover licensing, franchising and liability. For example, dealers must renew franchise and state licensing agreements annually.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure that it is compliant with the EPA's regulations concerning the storage of hazardous materials?
FAQs.answer: Dealerships that store more than 10,000 pounds of gasoline or diesel fuel, or reportable quantities of other chemicals, must submit an emergency and hazardous chemical inventory form to their local emergency planning commission, state emergency response commission and local fire department.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Due to the industry's high fragmented nature, profit margins often vary between operators, depending on the company's size and product offerings. In 2023, the average industry profit margin is expected to account for 6.8% of industry revenue.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for cash flow seasonality?
FAQs.answer: Weather conditions can significantly affect industry sales. Prolonged winter conditions, natural disasters and sustained high winds can prove detrimental for industry operators, as boating use generally declines.

FAQs.question: Do you closely monitor changes in technology? What do you do to obtain dealer agreements with boat manufacturers?
FAQs.answer: Ability to clearly specify requirements to suppliers. Boat dealers need to obtain dealer agreements with boat manufacturers that can maximize margins.

FAQs.question: Where is your business located? Do your locations experience heavy traffic?
FAQs.answer: Maintenance of excellent customer relations. Maintaining strong customer relationships will likely result in repeat sales. Having a convenient location will also help operators remain relevant. For example, boat dealers located near a body of water will likely be more successful than one in the middle of a city. This also pertains to the repair segment of the industry.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain optimum stock levels? What factors affect demand and stock levels?
FAQs.answer: Since boat inventories are typically expensive, the ability to control inventory levels is an important success factor for industry participants.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor changes in consumer leisure time availability? How will increasing leisure time affect your production?
FAQs.answer: A rise in leisure time may lead to an increase in the number of individuals that are willing to spend time boating and, in turn, purchase industry goods.

FAQs.question: Do you track trends in consumer confidence? How do changes in consumer confidence affect the industry?
FAQs.answer: When consumer perceptions of the economy are high and positive, households tend to freely spend on luxury items, such as recreational boats.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of rising disposable income levels? How can you appeal to consumers with lower disposable income?
FAQs.answer: Recreational boats are considered discretionary and luxury purchases; therefore, a rise in household disposable income increases the propensity for consumers to purchase industry goods, thus boosting demand. The industry may appeal to consumers with lower disposable income levels since repair services are included. Consumers with lower disposable income are more likely to opt for repair services rather than buying new boats.
